items.title: Scorpions in Rome Italy
items.summary: Watch Your Step!A friend of mine in 1969 from the Rome school…
items.content_html:
Watch Your Step!

A friend of mine in 1969 from the Rome school was interested in archaeology and he arranged a meetup with him at a major Roman underground subway stop so that we could go exploring.

So we meetup at the subway entrance, both of us carrying long handle shovels, and we walk down the stairs to board the subway to a part of town I was not familiar with. He knew where we were going, so we get off at mysterious subway stop. We exit the subway, walk up the stairs to the surface streets, and then walk for 45 minutes, block after block.

My friend suddenly says, we are here, and points across the street to this strange clay colored mountain that takes up a whole square block.

The mount was huge by any standards.

The mount covered an area of 20,000 square meters (220,000 sq ft) at its base and with a volume of approximately 580,000 cubic meters (760,000 cu yd). It had a circumference of nearly a kilometer (0.6 mi) and stands 35 meters (115 ft) high.

 

My friend said CLIMB!

So we slowly climbed up this mount, and I cannot identify what we are walking on, but each footstep you heard a crunch.

It turns out to be an estimated 53 million broken pottery, used to carry oil for lamps.

This entire street block was just a enormous mountain of clay pottery pieces.

I had never heard of this place.

Monte Testaccio


After a lot of climbing we got to the top and the entire mount back in 1969 was just like it was back in 140 BC. The pile grew each century exponentially to the height of 115 feet that it was that day.

My friend said it was time to dig, so we used our shovels to turn over piles of old pottery pieces, hoping for a collection of shards that we could reconstruct back into pot.

No luck. What we did find was thousands of black scorpions hiding from the sun under the cool clay pottery pieces.

I yelled to my friend to run and we did kind of a controlled run off the mount to street level. Once we got over that shock, we checked each other's clothes and hair in case scorpions hitched a ride. Thank goodness none were found.

So we made the long walk back to the subway entrance, caught a subway back to the main part of Rome, except we detoured to go to a restaurant that served American style food like hamburgers and milk shakes.

This restaurant was located on a very popular tourist street with some jet setters and the like.

So we walk down this street in broad daylight, two American teenagers carrying shovels head to the place.

The restaurant has no tables, with a little stand up area, which is not unusual for Rome, because of the valuable real estate.

So we order out hamburgers and milk shakes and chow down while standing on the street, leaning against the wall. The food was amazing.

We then caught another subway to get to each of our homes.

It was Saturday and only my Mom and Brother were home, my Father was working, which was not unusual for a weekend.

My Father came home late for supper and right away he asks why I was walking on the ritzy street with a shovel.

I was so stunned that he knew, that I could not lie and told him about my adventure.

He told me never do that again, to take shovels into town and walk around with them.

He also never told me how he knew.

It took me like 20 years to figure out the puzzle.

Number one was that he did not want a CIA kid to bring attention to himself or the family in public.

Number two was that his work that Saturday was to help man an CIA Observation Post (OP) to watch that street and saw me and my friend with the shovels.

The Agency liked to monitor key important streets for VIP people, diplomats, foreign intelligence Agents, Embassy and Consulate employees, and many other "hot" targeted people.

The OP used various surveillance tools like binoculars, telescopes and the like to physically monitor people traffic.

Little did I know that I stumbled onto CIA surveillance.

items.title: The Garage Fortress
items.summary: Security is an illusionHe forgot his keys. There we were, sitting in…
items.content_html:
Security is an illusion

He forgot his keys.

There we were, sitting in the car, looking at a locked house and garage door. Our driveway at the Plano Texas house was in the back and it led up to the two-car garage. But my conscientious Dad that secured the house every time we left had locked it. Except this time I was sure that he had done himself in.

He was his own worst enemy.

Once he discovered that he had no house keys on him, he walked up to the garage door, removed something from his shirt pocket, bent down just slightly, and inserted something into garage door lock. About 8 seconds later, the handle turned and the garage door slid up at his fingertips. I was dumbfounded. How did he open the garage without a key? He finally told me.

He habitually carried a open ended leather comb case with a metal comb in his shirt pocket. But next to the metal comb was two lock picks and a tension bar. The metal comb kept the picks from getting bent and held the picks in the case.

Turns out that he could open most American locks with just two types of picks and a tension bar. I asked how he picked the lock so fast. He said that the U.S. Treasury had trained him as an ATF agent to pick locks and that the Agency gave him even further training.

He had picked thousands of locks over the years and many different types.

It was as natural to him to pick a lock as it was for me to turn a doorknob and walk in a room. And I had seen many movies and TV shows by that time that showed spies and criminals picking locks by crouching down and looking into the key way as they picked.

I asked why he did not do that crouching method. He said that he was trained to walk up to a door and pick it in the same amount of time and appearance as if he had a key. He could feel the pins in the key way with the pick and manipulate them at will. Most good locksmiths can pick locks but not in such an innocuous manner. When he was in the field, he did not want to give even the hint that he was picking a lock, because he would have drawn unnecessary attention to himself.

I asked the next logical question, were the lock picks illegal to own for a private citizen that was not a locksmith? (In the past)

His answer was yes.

But then he said how often would a police officer search his comb case since he had a clean criminal history and would not give the officer any reason to search him.

So I got to see a side of my Father in action, in his element, that I had not seen before.

items.title: Frankfurt Bunker
items.summary: WWII Bunker in GermanyWhen we moved to Germany we lived in two places.
items.content_html:
WWII Bunker in Germany

When we moved to Germany we lived in two places. The first was a temporary situation at an apartment in downtown Frankfurt. The second place we lived for the longer term of the remaining two years was at an old German military apartment complex.

The complex was built before or during WWII and it had housed a lot of German soldiers.

It had an extensive underground tunnel system that connected each apartment building to a central bunker, in a spoke and hub configuration. We moved there in the early 60's and all the tunnels had been cemented over. The central bunker had a surface entrance in concrete that said "1944". The complex also had a long tunnel under the highway to a hospital far way.

I use to dig a lot in the dirt around the bunker hoping to find old German artifacts and I did find a 5 pfennig from 1944. This picture is a 10 pfennig.

During that time period my Father did a lot traveling, to other countries in Europe and to the Middle East.

One time he came home from a long business trip was wearing a beard, and me and my Brother hardly recognized him.

 

Who is that stranger?

He brought back many gifts from the Middle East, including two Keffiyehs and a Bible that had a hard wood book cover made from a tree in Jerusalem.


My Father stopped in Luxembourg on his return trip from the Middle East and visited someones house. I do not know if the house belonged to a friend, diplomat, or Agent but this person took this joke picture of my Father wearing one of the Keffiyehs. My Father made the joke "Lawrence of Luxembourg" instead of Lawrence of Arabia. 

Because of the family travels, I started collecting coins of foreign countries. My Father would never tell me where he had been doing CIA operations but he would come home and empty his pockets of his loose change into my collection. That was an OPSEC breach that he did on purpose to please me, to help my collection grow and indirectly tell me about his adventures.

items.title: Dangerous Mango
items.summary: Operation Mango: CIA mission In Vientiane, the second house we lived in,…
items.content_html:
Operation Mango: CIA mission


In Vientiane, the second house we lived in, it had a decent sized courtyard. [story]

I would ride my bicycle around the perimeter of the yard and I did not wear a shirt because of the heat that I generated in that high heat and humidity environment.

As I rode underneath a tree on the edge of the courtyard, the tree would scrape my back over and over again, as I ducked down going past it. I developed some kind of rash and my Mother took me in the dispensary to see the America doctor.

The doctor examined me and asked questions about my physical activities that could have contributed to this rash.

I told him about the tree and he asked my Mother what kind of tree it was. She said it was a mango tree.

After some more examination of the rash the doctor made the following declaration.

The doctor said that I had the rare tropical mango rash

and to make the rash go away, to avoid the tree.

We all had a good laugh over this "rare affliction" of the mango rash, and it became folk lore within the family.

The fear was that I had contracted some strange jungle infection, and it turned out to be nothing but skin irritation from the tree.

So this closed a chapter in the dangerous mango saga.

Every time I see a mango in the grocery store I remember this story and chuckle.

items.title: Pakse Hell
items.summary: Flying into Hell in Pakse LaosWhen my Mom, Brother and I needed…
items.content_html:
Flying into Hell in Pakse Laos

When my Mom, Brother and I needed to leave Savannakhet after the infamous Mekong River swim, we jumped on a Air America C-47 cargo plane for a ride back to Vientiane.

Except for one little fact, that the flight we got on was on a dogleg trip down the Southern part of Laos. It left Vientiane with passengers, stopped in Savannakhet to let people on and off, then off to Pakse, get passengers on and off, then back to Vientiane.

The cargo airplanes of Air America never flew very high, so no need for a side door or pressurized cabin.

A few of the passengers that were already on the plane were a music band of a few young guys with long hair. They were headed to Pakse to play music there. On the flight from Savannakhet to Pakse, they would stand by the open back door while in flight and lean into the wind and look around.

I thought that one quick bank maneuver by the pilot and this kid would go out the door. This was the beginning of a very long and frightful day.

So none of us were prepared to fly into Pakse, which was at the time was a beehive of war activity.

Pakse Laos

Pakse was in a very strategic geographic location to support the Secret War and the Vietnam War itself.

Airplanes out of Pakse could easily attack the Ho Chi Minh Trail (HCMT), enemy troops in Southern and Central Laos, or enemy troops in Vietnam.

As our plane approached the Pakse "airport", we flew pretty low and were dodging mountains. Suddenly the wings on the plane began to wiggle violently and we slammed onto the end of the PSP (Marsden) steel planking runway, taxied over near some military fighter planes and parked. The entire "airport" was built with PSP.

The band exited the plane and ran across the airfield with a armed escort to a building in the distance. That was one tough gig to play at I bet.

Once the band had left we got very strict and stern instructions NOT to leave the airplane while we sat on the ground for awhile.

So we looked out the windows and missing door to see chaos in action. Trucks racing about, military planes and Air America planes and helicopters taking on munitions and fuel. Military and CIA contract airplane crews running about. [story of Ravens]

The big lie was that officially there were no US military soldiers in Laos, since it was neutral. [story]

Finally the pilot fired up the engines, we taxied out to the main runway and took off at a steep angle, with the wings wiggling again.

We made it back safely to Vientiane with any more incidents.

The whole story of what had happened was not explained to me until years later.

Enemy snipers, either Pathet Lao (PL), Vietcong (VC), or North Vietnamese Army (NVA) were very active at the airport the day we flew into Pakse.

The snipers sat in the deep jungle at the end of the runway and took shots at the American airplanes as they came to land, because when landing a plane, the sniper knows where to zero in their telescopic sight.

I do not recall hearing any gunshots landing or taking off. But maybe it did happen, I will never know.

So the avoidance technique by the pilot was:

* Approach from a low angle behind mountains
* Dive quickly to the runway
* Wiggle the wings to distract the snipers and change course slightly

I think not knowing at the time did help some.

items.title: The CIA Nurses and I
items.summary: The CIA Nurses and I Went to WarTo prepare for moving to SEA…
items.content_html:
The CIA Nurses and I Went to War

To prepare for moving to SEA (Southeast Asia), Laos specifically, the family got vaccinations at the CIA Headquarters, Langley Virginia.

Because Laos is relatively primitive with no health standard and has lots of jungles, a laundry list of vaccinations are needed, twice before you depart.

Many diseases that do not exist in the United States do exist in Laos.

Off the top of my head, here is a partial list of vaccinations we had to get:

* Typhoid
* Typhus
* Hepatitis A
* Plague #1
* Plague #2
* Japanese Encephalitis
* Malaria

Add all of that to the standard vaccinations you must get too.

One of the vaccinations was especially awful. It was the Gamma Globulin (GG) that had to be kept in the fridge until just before the nurse injects it into your hip.

The needle is a very large gauge and having it sunk into your hip was super painful. The serum is extra thick and the nurse has to really push it into your side. It seems like it takes minutes to her to finish, just my perception of this hellish procedure.

As a kid with no warning from the nurse as to what to expect, she just jammed the needle into my side and pushed like she had somewhere else to go.

That GG shot traumatized me and I got a real fear of needles after that.

Let me restart this story by telling you this.

The first time I walked across the CIA Seal with the eagle in tile on the floor, I asked my Father what did the letters spell, and he just shuffled me along and did not say anything.

The nurses at CIA were old, experienced nurses that spent years working with the military, giving vaccinations to soldiers, and they were very crusty if you know what I mean.

The CIA nurses had ZERO bedside manners or patience for kids.

So a visit to their medical office was like, sit in that room and wait, they walk in, get the vaccinations ready, slam them into your arms and legs (or hips), and then they leave. No hello or goodbye or idle chitchat.

Suddenly for our second visit we switched to the State Department medical offices for vaccinations.

I think the CIA finally realized that they were not helping Agents maintain their cover by having the family inside the CIA HQ.

The State Department had much more experience with giving kids vaccinations, so that was a huge relief.

Part of my nightmare was over but little did I know what was coming to our family while in Laos.

items.title: Why Laos Stories Mostly
items.summary: Why Laos All the Time?Why so much about Laos because you did…
items.content_html:
Why Laos All the Time?

Why so much about Laos because you did live other places too?

* Only war zone as a CIA family member I have been to
* Only CIA conflict I got to see up close and personal
* I was 11-13 so my memories are deeper
* I will talk about Germany, Italy, Virginia, Pennsylvania, North Carolina

Laos effected my Family and myself profoundly, with lingering issues even today.

I have a type of PTSD because I was just a kid and not prepared to witness all the death, destruction, fear, and anxiousness. My Father did not handle the pressures well and he started to unravel.

While the family was in the CIA, we first moved to:

* Fairfax Virginia
* Frankfurt Germany
* Fairfax Virginia
* Vientiane Laos
* Rome Italy
* Fairfax Virginia
* Texas: When my Father retired

I was asked recently why the CIA would send an entire family into a war zone like that.

I did not have an answer.

items.title: Laos CIA Milk Run
items.summary: Milk Run, the 50 Kip Air America (AA) flew regular scheduled flights…
items.content_html:
Milk Run, the 50 Kip

Air America (AA) flew regular scheduled flights to transport food, fresh milk, cargo, ammo, and people (Diplomats, CIA, Sheep Dipped Soldiers, and Nurses) around Laos and Thailand.

The daily flights from Vientiane to Bangkok Thailand and back were such a common place event that it became known as the "Milk Run", as in going to the store to get milk. AA and CIA flippantly called it the 50 Kip, Kip being the local money and 50 Kip at the time was worth ten cents.



Laos did not produce good cows milk so it had to be daily imported from Bangkok. Even the Thai milk was not great compared to American dairies. [story]

The airplanes that AA used for the Milk Run were old WWII transport aircraft like the DC-3 and C-47. But they were always missing the side doors since the airplane was a work horse and did double duty dropping rice and cargo by parachute, so the doors would get in the way.

Air America: CIA Airline : Wikipedia

The aircraft Load Master aka Kicker (Guy that pushed cargo out the door with attached parachutes) needed a door free from obstacles. The aircraft also had a cord running down the top of the ceiling, to clip on the cargo packages to.

The term Milk Run and 50 Kip were a bit of an inside baseball terms that was only used by the CIA people in the field. On a commercial flight (Royal Air Lao) out of Vientiane on our way out of the country, I accidentally said something about this flight will be true luxury compared to the 50 Kip flight.

My Mom turned white because I could have blown our cover, so she very discretely told me to be quiet. It was not until we got to Hawaii that I realized that the Milk Run / 50 Kip linkage would have been bad.

50 Kip Flight = CIA

Not good.

I had to learn how to maintain cover and never reveal too much.

It was life and death for many people, not a video game that you could restart with no consequences.

This was a big burden for a 12 year old.

items.title: Air Amercia : CIA
items.summary: CIA Taxi and Cargo ServiceAir America (AA) was a large private airline…
items.content_html:
CIA Taxi and Cargo Service

Air America (AA) was a large private airline that was owned by the CIA. AA flew a large variety of special aircraft into very dangerous situations, carrying food like bags of rice, people ( both civilians and "customers i.e. CIA" ), medical supplies, ammo, fuel, and animals like oxen, pigs, and chickens.

Air America: CIA

AA was like a taxi and cargo service on demand for any CIA people or operation.

Some of the Aircraft they flew were STOL (Short Takeoff and Landing) aircraft. They are extremely handy at landing on tiny runways in the jungle and taking back off.

C-47 Skytrain

 

Helio Courier (STOL)

Pilatus PC-6 Porter (STOL)

 

C-130 Hercules

 T-28
